canonical_explanation.text: Amines are derivatives of ammonia in which one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups. They are classified as primary (R-NH2), secondary (R2NH), or tertiary (R3N) based on the number of hydrogen atoms replaced. A quaternary ammonium salt has four organic groups attached to nitrogen and carries a positive charge. Nomenclature follows IUPAC rules: the suffix '-amine' is added to the name of the parent alkane chain, and the position of the -NH2 group is indicated by a number. Common names use the prefix 'amino-' or name the alkyl groups followed by 'amine'. Amines are prepared by reduction of nitro compounds (using Sn/HCl or catalytic hydrogenation), ammonolysis of alkyl halides (giving a mixture of primary, secondary, tertiary amines and quaternary salts), Gabriel phthalimide synthesis (selective for primary amines), and Hoffmann bromamide degradation (converts amides to primary amines with one fewer carbon). Physical properties include higher boiling points than alkanes of comparable mass due to hydrogen bonding (primary > secondary > tertiary in boiling point), solubility in water for lower members, and a characteristic fishy smell. Basicity of amines depends on electron density on nitrogen: in the gas phase, alkyl groups increase basicity by induction (tertiary > secondary > primary), but in aqueous solution, solvation and steric effects alter the order so that secondary amines are generally the most basic among aliphatic amines. Aromatic amines like aniline are much weaker bases because the lone pair on nitrogen delocalises into the benzene ring. Important reactions include alkylation (with alkyl halides), acylation (with acid chlorides/anhydrides to form amides), carbylamine reaction (primary amines + CHCl3 + KOH give isocyanides), reaction with nitrous acid (primary aliphatic amines give alcohols + N2; primary aromatic amines at 0-5 degree C give diazonium salts), Hinsberg test distinguishing primary, secondary, and tertiary amines using benzenesulphonyl chloride, and electrophilic aromatic substitution in aniline which occurs at ortho and para positions due to the -NH2 group being activating and ortho/para directing. Diazonium salts (ArN2+ X-) are prepared by treating primary aromatic amines with NaNO2 and HCl at 0-5 degree C (diazotisation). They undergo Sandmeyer reaction (replacement of N2+ by Cl, Br, CN using Cu salts), Gattermann reaction (using Cu powder), Schiemann reaction (ArN2+BF4- gives ArF on heating), and coupling reactions with phenols and amines to form azo dyes. Diazonium salts are extremely important synthetic intermediates because they allow introduction of groups that cannot be directly substituted onto a benzene ring.
rules: Amines are classified as primary (1 degree), secondary (2 degree), or tertiary (3 degree) based on the number of alkyl/aryl groups on nitrogen.
Gabriel phthalimide synthesis produces only primary amines; Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts RCONH2 to RNH2 (one fewer carbon).
Basicity order in aqueous solution for aliphatic amines is generally: secondary > primary > tertiary, due to combined inductive, steric, and solvation effects.
Aniline is a weaker base than cyclohexylamine because the lone pair on nitrogen delocalises into the aromatic ring.
Carbylamine reaction is specific to primary amines: RNH2 + CHCl3 + KOH gives RNC (foul-smelling isocyanide).
Primary aromatic amines react with NaNO2/HCl at 0-5 degree C to form diazonium salts; primary aliphatic amines give unstable diazonium salts that immediately decompose to alcohols.
Hinsberg test: primary amines form sulphonamide soluble in alkali; secondary amines form sulphonamide insoluble in alkali; tertiary amines do not react.
Sandmeyer reaction replaces -N2+ with -Cl, -Br, or -CN using CuCl, CuBr, or CuCN respectively.
Diazonium coupling with phenols/amines gives azo compounds (Ar-N=N-Ar'), which are coloured dyes.
Acylation of amines with acetyl chloride or acetic anhydride gives N-substituted amides; this reaction reduces the basicity and nucleophilicity of nitrogen.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a secondary amine?
questions.explanation_correct: (CH3)2NH is dimethylamine, a secondary amine because two hydrogen atoms of ammonia are replaced by methyl groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH3NH2 is a primary amine (one H replaced), (CH3)3N is a tertiary amine (three H replaced), and C6H5NH2 (aniline) is a primary aromatic amine.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of C6H5NH2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The IUPAC name for C6H5NH2 is benzenamine (or benzenamine). Aniline is the common name, not the IUPAC name.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aniline and aminobenzene are common names. Phenylamine is an acceptable trivial name but not the IUPAC systematic name. The IUPAC name is benzenamine.

questions.question_text: Which method selectively produces primary amines from alkyl halides?
questions.explanation_correct: Gabriel phthalimide synthesis uses potassium phthalimide to react with alkyl halides, followed by hydrolysis, selectively yielding primary amines without forming secondary or tertiary amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ammonolysis of alkyl halides gives a mixture of primary, secondary, and tertiary amines. Reductive amination and Friedel-Crafts reaction are not selective methods for primary amine synthesis.

questions.question_text: In the Hoffmann bromamide degradation of ethanamide (CH3CONH2) with Br2/NaOH, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts an amide RCONH2 to a primary amine RNH2 with one fewer carbon atom. Ethanamide (CH3CONH2) gives methylamine (CH3NH2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethylamine has two carbons and is not the product. The reaction removes one carbon, so ethanamide (2C) gives methylamine (1C). Dimethylamine is secondary and acetonitrile is a nitrile.

questions.question_text: Which reagent is used to reduce nitrobenzene to aniline?
questions.explanation_correct: Sn/HCl is the classical reagent for reducing nitrobenzene to aniline. The tin acts as the reducing agent in acidic medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na/ethanol (Birch reduction) reduces aromatic rings. NaBH4 reduces carbonyl groups but not nitro groups. KMnO4 is an oxidising agent, not a reducing agent.

questions.question_text: Lower aliphatic amines are soluble in water because they:

options.text: Can form hydrogen bonds with water

questions.explanation_correct: Lower aliphatic amines have N-H bonds and a lone pair on nitrogen, allowing them to form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, making them soluble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amines are polar, not non-polar. Lower amines have low molecular masses. Amines are bases, not acids. Their water solubility is due to hydrogen bonding.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of boiling point: (I) C2H5NH2, (II) C2H5OH, (III) (CH3)3N. The correct order is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethanol (II) has the highest boiling point due to strong O-H hydrogen bonding. Ethylamine (I) has N-H hydrogen bonding, which is weaker than O-H. Trimethylamine (III) is a tertiary amine with no N-H bonds and cannot form hydrogen bonds among its own molecules, giving the lowest boiling point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The strength of hydrogen bonding follows O-H > N-H > no H-bonding. So ethanol > ethylamine > trimethylamine in boiling point order.

questions.question_text: Ammonolysis of methyl bromide with excess ammonia primarily gives:

options.text: A mixture of primary, secondary, and tertiary amines

questions.explanation_correct: Ammonolysis of alkyl halides gives a mixture of products because the primary amine formed can further react with more alkyl halide to give secondary, then tertiary amines, and finally quaternary ammonium salts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reaction is not selective. The primary amine acts as a nucleophile and reacts further, producing a mixture of all three types of amines and quaternary salts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conversions is achieved by Gabriel phthalimide synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Gabriel synthesis converts an alkyl halide (RX) to a primary amine (RNH2) via potassium phthalimide as the nucleophile, followed by hydrolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: R2NH (secondary amine) is not produced by Gabriel synthesis. ArNH2 to ArOH involves diazotisation. RCONH2 to RNH2 is Hoffmann bromamide degradation, not Gabriel synthesis.

questions.question_text: The correct order of increasing basicity of methylamines in aqueous solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: In aqueous solution, the basicity order is (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > (CH3)3N. This is because solvation stabilisation of the conjugate acid (protonated amine) is best for secondary, and steric hindrance reduces solvation in tertiary amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In the gas phase, the inductive effect alone would predict tertiary > secondary > primary. But in aqueous solution, solvation effects make secondary amines the strongest bases among aliphatic methylamines.

questions.question_text: Aniline is a weaker base than cyclohexylamine because:

options.text: The -NH2 group in aniline is electron-donating
The lone pair on nitrogen in aniline is delocalised into the benzene ring
Cyclohexylamine has a higher molecular mass
Aniline cannot form a salt with HCl

questions.explanation_correct: In aniline, the lone pair on nitrogen participates in resonance with the benzene ring, reducing its availability for protonation and making it a weaker base compared to cyclohexylamine where no such delocalisation occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The -NH2 group donates electrons to the ring (making it less basic itself). Molecular mass does not determine basicity. Aniline does form salts with HCl; it is just a weaker base.

questions.question_text: The carbylamine reaction is a test for:
questions.explanation_correct: The carbylamine (isocyanide) reaction is specific to primary amines. When heated with chloroform and alcoholic KOH, primary amines give foul-smelling isocyanides (R-NC).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secondary and tertiary amines do not give isocyanides under these conditions. The test is exclusively for primary amines (both aliphatic and aromatic).

questions.question_text: When aniline reacts with acetyl chloride, the product formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Aniline undergoes acylation with acetyl chloride (CH3COCl) to form acetanilide (C6H5NHCOCH3). This is a nucleophilic substitution where the nitrogen attacks the carbonyl carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p-Aminoacetophenone would require Friedel-Crafts acylation. Benzamide is from benzoyl chloride + ammonia. N-Methylaniline is an alkylation product, not acylation.

questions.question_text: When ethylamine reacts with nitrous acid (NaNO2/HCl), the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Primary aliphatic amines react with nitrous acid to give unstable diazonium salts that immediately decompose, releasing N2 gas and forming the corresponding alcohol. Ethylamine gives ethanol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stable diazonium salts are formed only by primary aromatic amines at 0-5 degree C. Primary aliphatic amines give alcohols with evolution of N2 gas.

questions.question_text: In the Hinsberg test, a primary amine reacts with benzenesulphonyl chloride (C6H5SO2Cl) to form a product that is:
questions.explanation_correct: A primary amine forms a sulphonamide (R-NHSO2C6H5) that still has an N-H hydrogen. This hydrogen is acidic enough to dissolve in alkali (NaOH), forming a soluble sodium salt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secondary amine sulphonamides are insoluble in alkali because they lack N-H. Tertiary amines do not react with benzenesulphonyl chloride. The primary amine derivative is specifically soluble in NaOH.

questions.question_text: Electrophilic substitution in aniline occurs preferentially at:
questions.explanation_correct: The -NH2 group is a strong activating group and an ortho/para director. The lone pair on nitrogen donates electron density into the ring, increasing electron density at ortho and para positions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meta directors are electron-withdrawing groups like -NO2 and -CN. The -NH2 group directs incoming electrophiles to ortho and para positions, not meta or equally to all.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT increase the basicity of an amine?

options.text: Resonance of the lone pair with an aromatic ring
Alkyl groups attached to nitrogen (inductive effect)
Increasing the electron density on nitrogen

questions.explanation_correct: Resonance of the lone pair with an aromatic ring delocalises the electron density away from nitrogen, reducing its availability for protonation and thus decreasing basicity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electron-donating groups, alkyl groups (via +I effect), and increased electron density on nitrogen all increase basicity. Resonance with the ring withdraws electron density from nitrogen, making it less basic.

questions.question_text: Acylation of amines is preferred over alkylation because:

options.text: The acylated product does not undergo further acylation, avoiding polysubstitution

questions.explanation_correct: In acylation, the amide product has reduced nucleophilicity because the lone pair on nitrogen is delocalised with the carbonyl group. This prevents further reaction, unlike alkylation which gives a mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acylation is not necessarily faster. Alkylation does not always require a catalyst. Acylation gives amides, not tertiary amines. The key advantage is avoiding polysubstitution.

questions.question_text: When aniline is treated with bromine water, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is so strongly activated by the -NH2 group that bromine water (a mild reagent) brominates all three available ortho and para positions to give 2,4,6-tribromoaniline as a white precipitate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mono-bromination requires controlled conditions (dissolving in acetic acid, using Lewis acid catalyst at low temperature). With bromine water, the -NH2 group activates the ring so strongly that tribromination occurs.

questions.question_text: Which amine gives a positive carbylamine test?
questions.explanation_correct: C2H5NH2 (ethylamine) is a primary amine and gives a positive carbylamine test, forming ethyl isocyanide with its characteristic offensive odour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: (C2H5)2NH is secondary, (C2H5)3N is tertiary, and (C2H5)2NCH3 is also tertiary. Only primary amines respond to the carbylamine test.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts are prepared by treating primary aromatic amines with NaNO2 and HCl at:
questions.explanation_correct: Diazonium salts are prepared at 0-5 degree C because they are unstable and decompose at higher temperatures. This process is called diazotisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At higher temperatures, diazonium salts decompose rapidly, releasing N2 gas. The reaction must be carried out in an ice bath at 0-5 degree C to keep the salt stable.

questions.question_text: The general formula of an arenediazonium salt is:
questions.explanation_correct: Arenediazonium salts have the general formula ArN2+ X-, where Ar is an aryl group and X- is an anion (commonly Cl- or BF4-). The key feature is the -N2+ (diazo) group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ArNO2 is a nitro compound. ArNH3+ Cl- is an amine salt. ArCONH2 is an amide. Diazonium salts specifically have the -N=N+ or -N2+ functional group.

questions.question_text: In the Sandmeyer reaction, benzenediazonium chloride is treated with CuCN/KCN to give:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Sandmeyer reaction, the diazonium group (-N2+) is replaced by -CN when treated with CuCN/KCN, giving benzonitrile (C6H5CN) with the release of N2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CuCl gives chlorobenzene, water gives phenol, and the Schiemann reaction gives fluorobenzene. CuCN/KCN specifically introduces the -CN group.

questions.question_text: Benzenediazonium tetrafluoroborate on heating gives fluorobenzene. This reaction is known as:
questions.explanation_correct: The Balz-Schiemann (or Schiemann) reaction involves heating the diazonium tetrafluoroborate salt (ArN2+ BF4-) to give the aryl fluoride (ArF) + N2 + BF3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sandmeyer reaction uses CuX (X = Cl, Br, CN). Gattermann reaction uses Cu powder with HX. Kolbe reaction is electrolysis of carboxylate salts. The fluorination via BF4- is the Balz-Schiemann reaction.

questions.question_text: When benzenediazonium chloride reacts with phenol in a mildly alkaline medium, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: This is an azo coupling reaction. The diazonium ion acts as a weak electrophile and couples with the electron-rich phenol at the para position to give p-hydroxyazobenzene, an orange azo dye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Azobenzene is formed from coupling with another amine. Biphenyl forms from Gomberg-Bachmann reaction. Diphenyl ether is from Williamson synthesis. Coupling with phenol gives para-hydroxyazobenzene.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reactions of diazonium salts does NOT involve loss of nitrogen gas?
questions.explanation_correct: In coupling reactions, the diazonium group is retained in the product as the -N=N- (azo) linkage. Both nitrogen atoms remain in the molecule. In all other listed reactions, N2 gas is lost.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sandmeyer, Schiemann, and Gattermann reactions all involve replacement of the -N2+ group with another substituent, releasing N2 gas. Only coupling retains both nitrogen atoms.

questions.question_text: Benzenediazonium chloride on treatment with CuCl/HCl gives chlorobenzene. On treatment with CuBr/HBr it gives bromobenzene. These are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Sandmeyer reaction uses cuprous halides (CuCl or CuBr) to replace the diazonium group with the corresponding halide. CuCl gives ArCl and CuBr gives ArBr.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gattermann reaction uses copper powder (not cuprous salts). Wurtz and Fittig reactions involve coupling of alkyl/aryl halides with sodium metal. The use of Cu(I) salts is characteristic of Sandmeyer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following cannot be directly introduced into a benzene ring by electrophilic substitution but can be introduced via a diazonium salt?
questions.explanation_correct: Fluorine cannot be directly introduced onto benzene by electrophilic substitution in a controlled manner. However, via the Balz-Schiemann reaction (ArN2+ BF4- heated to give ArF), aryl fluorides are easily obtained.
questions.explanation_incorrect: -NO2 is introduced via nitration, -Br via bromination, and -Cl via chlorination. Only -F lacks a practical direct electrophilic substitution route and requires the diazonium salt pathway.

questions.question_text: Benzenediazonium chloride is warmed with water to give:
questions.explanation_correct: When warmed with water, benzenediazonium chloride undergoes hydrolysis: C6H5N2+ Cl- + H2O gives C6H5OH + N2 + HCl. Phenol is the organic product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aniline is the starting material for making the diazonium salt, not the product. Benzene and toluene are not formed. Hydrolysis of diazonium salt gives phenol.

questions.question_text: The Gattermann reaction differs from the Sandmeyer reaction in using:

options.text: Copper powder instead of cuprous salts

questions.explanation_correct: The Gattermann reaction uses copper powder (Cu) along with HCl or HBr to replace the diazonium group, while the Sandmeyer reaction uses cuprous salts (CuCl, CuBr, or CuCN).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zinc, silver, and iron are not used in either reaction. The key distinction is copper powder (Gattermann) versus cuprous salts (Sandmeyer).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a tertiary amine?
questions.explanation_correct: Triethylamine, (C2H5)3N, has all three hydrogen atoms of ammonia replaced by ethyl groups, making it a tertiary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diethylamine is secondary (two H replaced), ethylamine is primary (one H replaced), and aniline is a primary aromatic amine.

questions.question_text: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation of benzamide (C6H5CONH2) gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts RCONH2 to RNH2 with loss of one carbon. Benzamide (C6H5CONH2) gives aniline (C6H5NH2) as the carbonyl carbon is lost as CO2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzylamine (C6H5CH2NH2) has the same number of carbons as benzamide. Benzonitrile and nitrobenzene are entirely different compounds. The reaction removes the carbonyl carbon, giving the aryl amine.

questions.question_text: The reagents used in the carbylamine reaction are:
questions.explanation_correct: The carbylamine reaction uses chloroform (CHCl3) and alcoholic KOH with a primary amine to form an isocyanide. CHCl3 provides the carbon for the -NC group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CCl4, CH2Cl2, and CHI3 are not used in the carbylamine reaction. The specific combination of CHCl3 and alcoholic KOH is required to generate dichlorocarbene (:CCl2) which reacts with the primary amine.

questions.question_text: p-Toluidine (4-methylaniline) is a stronger base than aniline because:

options.text: The methyl group increases electron density on nitrogen via +I effect
The methyl group reduces the molecular mass
The methyl group blocks ortho substitution

questions.explanation_correct: The -CH3 group at the para position exerts a positive inductive (+I) effect, pushing electron density towards the ring and subsequently to the nitrogen, increasing its basicity relative to aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The methyl group is electron-donating, not electron-withdrawing. Molecular mass and steric blocking at ortho positions are irrelevant to basicity. The +I effect of -CH3 increases electron density on N.

questions.question_text: When a secondary amine reacts with nitrous acid, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Secondary amines (R2NH) react with nitrous acid (HNO2) to form N-nitrosoamines (R2N-N=O), which are yellow oily substances. This is a characteristic reaction of secondary amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alcohols are formed from primary aliphatic amines + HNO2. Diazonium salts form from primary aromatic amines. Isocyanides form from primary amines + CHCl3/KOH (carbylamine test).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is most basic in aqueous solution?
questions.explanation_correct: p-Methoxyaniline has an electron-donating -OCH3 group at the para position, which increases electron density on nitrogen by +M effect, making it the most basic among the given aromatic amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p-Nitroaniline is the least basic due to the strong electron-withdrawing -NO2 group. p-Chloroaniline is less basic than aniline due to -I effect of Cl. p-Methoxyaniline is most basic due to the +M effect of -OCH3.

questions.question_text: The common name of the simplest aromatic amine C6H5NH2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is the common name for C6H5NH2, the simplest primary aromatic amine. It is a colourless oily liquid that darkens on exposure to air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Toluene is C6H5CH3, phenol is C6H5OH, and anisole is C6H5OCH3. Aniline is the aromatic compound with an -NH2 group directly attached to the benzene ring.

questions.question_text: The reduction of CH3CN with LiAlH4 gives:
questions.explanation_correct: LiAlH4 reduces the nitrile group (-CN) to a primary amine (-CH2NH2). CH3CN (acetonitrile, 2 carbons) is reduced to CH3CH2NH2 (ethylamine, 2 carbons).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methylamine has only 1 carbon. Dimethylamine is secondary. Acetamide is a partial reduction product. LiAlH4 fully reduces -CN to -CH2NH2, preserving the carbon count.

questions.question_text: The process of converting a primary aromatic amine to a diazonium salt is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Diazotisation is the process of treating a primary aromatic amine with NaNO2 and HCl at 0-5 degree C to form a diazonium salt (ArN2+ Cl-).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dimerisation is joining two identical molecules. Deamination is removal of an amino group. Dehydration is removal of water. The specific process of forming -N2+ from -NH2 using NaNO2/HCl is diazotisation.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts of aliphatic amines are not useful in synthesis because they are:

options.text: Too stable and do not react
Highly unstable and decompose immediately even at low temperatures

questions.explanation_correct: Aliphatic diazonium salts are extremely unstable and decompose immediately (even at 0 degree C) to give carbocations, N2 gas, and rearrangement products. Only aromatic diazonium salts are stable enough at 0-5 degree C for synthetic use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not stable â€” quite the opposite. Solubility and cost are not the issues. The extreme instability of aliphatic diazonium salts makes them synthetically useless.

questions.question_text: Which sequence correctly converts aniline to iodobenzene?

options.text: NaNO2/HCl at 0-5 degree C, then KI

questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is first diazotised with NaNO2/HCl at 0-5 degree C to form benzenediazonium chloride, which is then treated with KI to replace the -N2+ group with -I, giving iodobenzene + N2 + KCl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Direct iodination of aniline gives multiple products. Br2/FeBr3 gives bromobenzene. HI would not selectively give iodobenzene. The diazonium salt route with KI is the standard method for aryl iodides.

questions.question_text: Methylamine reacts with HCl to form:
questions.explanation_correct: Amines are basic and react with acids to form salts. Methylamine (CH3NH2) reacts with HCl to form methylammonium chloride (CH3NH3+ Cl-), an ionic salt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanol is an alcohol form. Chloromethane is a halide. Dimethylamine is a secondary amine. The reaction of a base (amine) with an acid (HCl) gives a salt.

questions.question_text: Which of the following amines cannot be prepared by Gabriel phthalimide synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Gabriel phthalimide synthesis works only with alkyl halides (SN2 mechanism). Aryl halides like chlorobenzene do not undergo SN2 reactions, so aromatic primary amines like aniline cannot be prepared by this method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methylamine, ethylamine, and butylamine are all primary aliphatic amines that can be prepared via Gabriel synthesis. Aniline is aromatic and cannot be prepared this way because aryl halides do not undergo nucleophilic substitution with phthalimide.

questions.question_text: To obtain monobromoaniline (para isomer), aniline is first treated with:

options.text: Acetic anhydride (to form acetanilide), then Br2/CH3COOH

questions.explanation_correct: The -NH2 group is so strongly activating that direct bromination gives 2,4,6-tribromoaniline. To get the mono-bromo product, the -NH2 is first protected by acetylation (forming acetanilide), then bromination gives mainly the para product, and finally hydrolysis restores the -NH2 group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bromine water directly gives tribromoaniline. NaOH treatment does not protect the amino group. HNO3 would oxidise the amino group. Acetylation is the standard protection strategy.

questions.question_text: Azo dyes are coloured because they contain:
questions.explanation_correct: Azo dyes are coloured because the -N=N- (azo) group acts as a chromophore, and it is conjugated with the aromatic rings on either side, creating an extended conjugated system that absorbs visible light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: -COOH, halogens, and -OH alone do not produce colour. The azo linkage (-N=N-) combined with aromatic rings creates extended conjugation responsible for visible light absorption.

questions.question_text: The order of basicity among NH3, CH3NH2, (CH3)2NH, C6H5NH2 in aqueous solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: In aqueous solution: (CH3)2NH is the most basic (inductive + good solvation), then CH3NH2 (one alkyl group), then NH3 (no alkyl groups), and C6H5NH2 is the least basic (resonance withdraws lone pair into ring).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aniline is always the weakest base due to resonance. Alkyl groups increase basicity via +I effect. In aqueous solution, dimethylamine is more basic than methylamine, and both are more basic than ammonia.

questions.question_text: Catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in the presence of Pd/C gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using Pd/C or Pt reduces the -NO2 group to -NH2, producing aniline. The aromatic ring is not reduced under these mild conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyclohexylamine would require reduction of the ring as well. Phenylhydrazine and azobenzene are partial reduction products obtained under different conditions. Pd/C with H2 fully reduces -NO2 to -NH2.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a coupling component for diazonium salts?
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol is an electron-rich aromatic compound that can undergo electrophilic substitution with the weakly electrophilic diazonium ion. The -OH group activates the ring sufficiently for coupling at the para position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrobenzene, benzoic acid, and chlorobenzene have electron-withdrawing or weakly activating groups that do not activate the ring sufficiently for coupling with the weak electrophile diazonium ion.

questions.question_text: p-Nitroaniline is a weaker base than aniline because the -NO2 group:

options.text: Withdraws electron density from nitrogen by -I and -M effects
Donates electrons to nitrogen by resonance
Has no electronic effect on nitrogen

questions.explanation_correct: The -NO2 group is a powerful electron-withdrawing group that decreases electron density on nitrogen through both -I (inductive) and -M (mesomeric/resonance) effects, reducing the availability of the lone pair for protonation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The -NO2 group does not donate electrons or increase electron density on nitrogen. It strongly withdraws electrons, making the amine much less basic than aniline.

questions.question_text: Benzenediazonium chloride on treatment with hypophosphorous acid (H3PO2) gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypophosphorous acid (H3PO2) reduces the diazonium group, replacing -N2+ with -H to give benzene. This reaction is useful for removing the amino group from a ring after it has served as a directing group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenol is obtained from hydrolysis with water. Chlorobenzene is obtained from Sandmeyer reaction. Aniline is the starting material. H3PO2 replaces -N2+ with -H, giving the parent aromatic hydrocarbon.
